clues: This colonial city is surrounded by three volcanoes.
Known for its preserved Spanish Baroque architecture.
fun_facts: Antigua was the capital of the Kingdom of Guatemala before it was abandoned after a series of earthquakes in 1773.
The city's full name is La Antigua Guatemala, meaning 'The Old Guatemala'.
trivia: This city was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.
Antigua hosts one of the world's largest Easter celebrations, with elaborate processions and carpets made of colored sawdust.

clues: This city is famous for its buildings painted in various shades of blue.
Nestled in the Rif Mountains in northwest Morocco.
fun_facts: Chefchaouen was painted blue originally by Jewish refugees in the 1930s, as blue represents the sky and heaven.
The city was founded in 1471 as a fortress to fight Portuguese invasions of northern Morocco.
trivia: This city's name comes from the Berber words for 'look at the horns,' referring to the mountain peaks above the town.
Chefchaouen was closed to European visitors until 1920.

clues: This city is built on a volcanic field with approximately 50 volcanoes.
Known as the 'City of Sails' due to its two harbors.
fun_facts: Auckland has the largest Polynesian population of any city in the world.
The city's Sky Tower is the tallest free-standing structure in the Southern Hemisphere.
trivia: This city was New Zealand's capital from 1841 until 1865.
Auckland is built on a narrow isthmus between two harbors, the Waitemata and the Manukau.

clues: This city is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
Known for its ghats along the Ganges River.
fun_facts: Varanasi is considered the spiritual capital of India and a holy city for Hindus, Jains, and Buddhists.
The city has nearly 100 ghats (steps leading to the river), most of which are used for bathing and ceremonies.
trivia: This city is where Buddha is believed to have founded Buddhism in 528 BCE.
Mark Twain once said of Varanasi: 'Older than history, older than tradition, older even than legend, and looks twice as old as all of them put together.'

clues: This city is the birthplace of flamenco dance.
Home to the world's largest Gothic cathedral.
fun_facts: Seville's Cathedral holds the tomb of Christopher Columbus.
The city's Plaza de España was used as a filming location for Star Wars: Episode II.
trivia: This city has the hottest summer temperatures in continental Europe, regularly exceeding 40°C (104°F).
Seville's Alcázar palace is the oldest royal palace still in use in Europe.

clues: This city is known for its sulfur baths and diverse architecture.
The capital lies on the banks of the Kura River.
fun_facts: Tbilisi's name comes from the Georgian word 'tbili,' meaning 'warm,' referring to its natural hot springs.
The city has been destroyed and rebuilt at least 29 times throughout its history.
trivia: This city has been the capital of Georgia since the 5th century.
Tbilisi's Old Town features an unusual mix of Eastern Orthodox churches, ornate Art Nouveau buildings, and Soviet Modernist structures.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of Eternal Spring' for its pleasant weather.
Famous for its cable car system connecting hillside neighborhoods.
fun_facts: Medellín was once considered one of the most dangerous cities in the world but has transformed into a model of urban innovation.
The city hosts the annual Flower Festival (Feria de las Flores), featuring elaborate flower arrangements.
trivia: This city was the birthplace of artist Fernando Botero, known for his sculptures of exaggerated human figures.
Medellín was the first city in the world to use cable cars for public transportation.

clues: This West African capital is known for its colonial-era architecture.
Located along the Gulf of Guinea.
fun_facts: Porto Novo means 'New Port' in Portuguese, named by Portuguese traders in the 16th century.
The city is home to the Royal Palaces of Abomey, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: This city is the official capital of Benin, though many government functions actually take place in Cotonou.
Porto Novo's Grande Mosquée is a famous example of Afro-Brazilian architecture, built by returned slaves from Brazil.

clues: This ancient trading port is famous for its lanterns and preserved buildings.
Known for its mix of Japanese, Chinese, and European architectural influences.
fun_facts: Hoi An was a major trading port from the 15th to 19th centuries.
The city's Old Town becomes car-free during the monthly Lantern Festival when only candles and lanterns provide light.
trivia: This city's name means 'peaceful meeting place'.
Hoi An was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1999.

clues: This ancient city was a major stop on the Silk Road.
Known for its well-preserved medieval center with over 140 protected buildings.
fun_facts: Bukhara is over 2,000 years old and was a major center of Islamic culture and learning.
The city has 11 madrassas (Islamic schools) and hundreds of mosques.
trivia: This city's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Bukhara was known as the 'Noble City' (Bukhara-i-Sharif) and the 'Dome of Islam' in the medieval Islamic world.

clues: This resort town is known as the adventure capital of the world.
Located on a lake surrounded by mountains called The Remarkables.
fun_facts: Queenstown is where commercial bungee jumping was invented by AJ Hackett in 1988.
The city was named because it was 'fit for Queen Victoria'.
trivia: This city's landscapes were featured in The Lord of the Rings films.
Queenstown hosts one of the largest winter festivals in the Southern Hemisphere.

clues: This city is the southernmost capital in the Americas.
Known for its beachfront promenade, the Rambla, which stretches for 22 kilometers.
fun_facts: Montevideo was founded by the Spanish in 1724 to counter Portuguese expansion.
The city's name either comes from 'Monte vide eu' (I saw a mountain) or 'Monte VI De Este a Oeste' (the sixth mountain from east to west).
trivia: This city was the site of the first FIFA World Cup final in 1930.
Montevideo's Carnival celebration is the longest in the world, lasting more than 40 days.

clues: This city is surrounded by volcanoes and was rebuilt several times after earthquakes.
Known for its colonial architecture and vibrant street art.
fun_facts: San Salvador sits in the 'Valley of the Hammocks,' named because the frequent earthquakes made the ground feel like a swinging hammock.
The city's Metropolitan Cathedral has survived multiple major earthquakes.
trivia: This city is home to El Boquerón, an inactive volcano with a crater over 5 km in circumference.
San Salvador's nickname is 'The City of Palms' due to its many palm trees.

clues: This city has one of the largest and best-preserved Spanish colonial districts in the Caribbean.
Known for its cobblestone streets and colorful buildings.
fun_facts: San Juan was founded in 1521, making it the second-oldest European-established capital city in the Americas.
The city's El Morro fortress has walls up to 140 feet thick in some places.
trivia: This city's historic district is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
San Juan's Calle del Cristo (Christ Street) got its name from a legend about a miracle that occurred there.

clues: This medieval city is crisscrossed by canals and often called the 'Venice of the North'.
Known for its well-preserved Gothic architecture and chocolates.
fun_facts: Bruges has been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 2000.
The city's name comes from the Old Norse word 'Bryggja' meaning 'harbor' or 'mooring place'.
trivia: This city was one of the world's first tourist destinations, attracting wealthy British travelers in the 19th century.
Bruges' belfry houses a treasury and a 47-bell carillon that still rings today.

clues: This city sits in a valley surrounded by the Himalayas.
Known for its numerous temples and Buddhist stupas.
fun_facts: Kathmandu has the densest concentration of UNESCO World Heritage sites in the world.
The city's Durbar Square contains more than 50 temples and palaces built between the 12th and 18th centuries.
trivia: This city's name comes from an ancient structure called Kasthamandap, which was sadly destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.
Kathmandu was once accessible only by foot until the first road was built in the 1950s.

clues: This city is known for its medieval walled Inner City and modern flame-shaped skyscrapers.
Located on the Caspian Sea and famous for its strong winds.
fun_facts: Baku means 'wind pounding city' in Persian, and is nicknamed the 'City of Winds'.
The city has natural 'eternal flames' caused by gas seeping through the ground.
trivia: This city's Flame Towers are designed to resemble flames, symbolizing Azerbaijan's nickname as 'The Land of Fire'.
Baku hosted the Eurovision Song Contest in 2012 and the European Games in 2015.

clues: This city was the historic capital of the Inca Empire.
Known for its stone walls built with incredible precision without mortar.
fun_facts: Cuzco's city layout was designed in the shape of a puma, a sacred animal to the Incas.
The city sits at an elevation of 3,399 meters (11,152 feet) above sea level.
trivia: This city's name means 'navel of the world' in Quechua.
Cuzco's Qoricancha temple was once covered in gold before Spanish colonization.

clues: This city is known for its golden-domed churches and Soviet architecture.
Located on the Dnieper River with a history spanning 1,500 years.
fun_facts: Kyiv is home to the deepest metro station in the world, Arsenalna, at 105.5 meters underground.
The city was founded by three brothers and their sister according to legend.
trivia: This city is often called the 'mother of Slavic cities' due to its important historical role.
Kyiv's Monastery of the Caves (Pechersk Lavra) contains a complex network of underground tunnels with mummified monks.

clues: This city's historic Stone Town is a maze of narrow streets.
Known for its spice trade and mix of African, Arab, and European influences.
fun_facts: Zanzibar City's Stone Town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was once the capital of the Omani Sultanate and a major center for the spice and slave trades.
trivia: This city was the birthplace of Freddie Mercury, the lead vocalist of the band Queen.
Zanzibar City's doorways are famous for their ornately carved wooden doors with brass studs, a tradition from India.

clues: This port city is known for its colorful merchant houses and maritime history.
Birthplace of the Solidarity movement that helped end Communist rule in Poland.
fun_facts: Gdansk is where World War II began with the German attack on the Polish Military Transit Depot on September 1, 1939.
The city has been part of both Poland and Germany throughout its history and was once a semi-autonomous city-state.
trivia: This city is famous for its amber, often called 'Baltic gold'.
Gdansk's old town was meticulously reconstructed after being 90% destroyed during World War II.

clues: This city is the world's diamond capital.
Known for its Gothic cathedral and connections to painter Peter Paul Rubens.
fun_facts: Antwerp handles 86% of the world's rough diamonds.
The city's Central Station is often cited as one of the most beautiful railway stations in the world.
trivia: This city's name supposedly comes from a legend about a giant's hand being cut off and thrown into the river.
Antwerp was the richest city in Europe in the 16th century.

clues: This city is divided by a river with chain bridges connecting both sides.
Known for its stunning thermal baths and Art Nouveau architecture.
fun_fact: The Hungarian Parliament Building has approximately 691 rooms and 20 kilometers of stairs!
Budapest has more thermal springs than any other capital city in the world, with over 120 springs.
trivia: The city was originally two separate cities, Buda and Pest, which merged in 1873.
Budapest's metro line 1 is the oldest underground railway system in continental Europe, opened in 1896.

clues: This city's marketplace is a maze of narrow streets filled with vendors.
Known for its distinctive red buildings and walls.
fun_fact: The locals call it 'The Red City' because of the red sandstone used in constructing its walls and buildings!
The famous Jemaa el-Fnaa square transforms completely from day to night, shifting from market to open-air restaurant.
trivia: Winston Churchill called this city 'the most lovely spot in the world' and often visited to paint its landscapes.
The city's name comes from the Berber words 'mur' (n) and 'akush,' meaning 'Land of God.'

clues: This city is known for its street art, coffee culture, and trams.
It hosts one of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments annually.
fun_fact: Melbourne has the largest Greek population outside of Greece in the world!
The city was briefly named 'Batmania' after one of its founders, John Batman, before being renamed.
trivia: Melbourne has the largest tram network in the world, stretching over 250 kilometers.
The city has been ranked as the world's most livable city seven times in a row by The Economist.

clues: This city sits in a valley surrounded by snow-capped Andean mountains.
You can ski in the morning and visit the beach in the afternoon from here.
fun_fact: The city has South America's tallest building, the 300-meter-high Gran Torre Santiago!
Santiago's metro system features beautiful art installations in many of its stations.
trivia: The city was founded in 1541 by Spanish conquistador Pedro de Valdivia.
Santiago's Central Market is housed in a stunning 19th-century wrought-iron building designed by Gustave Eiffel's team.

clues: This city features iconic twin towers that were once the tallest buildings in the world.
Known for its diversity of cultures, cuisines, and colonial architecture.
fun_fact: The name means 'muddy confluence' in Malay, referencing the meeting of the Klang and Gombak rivers!
The Petronas Twin Towers have a sky bridge connecting them at the 41st and 42nd floors.
trivia: The city has a 272-step rainbow-colored staircase leading to the Batu Caves, a Hindu shrine.
Kuala Lumpur was founded by tin miners in the 1850s at the confluence of two rivers.

clues: This city has a national park within its borders where you can see lions and giraffes.
Known as the 'Green City in the Sun' with a thriving tech industry.
fun_fact: Nairobi is the only capital city in the world with a national park inside its boundaries!
The city was founded as a railway depot on the Uganda Railway in 1899.
trivia: Nairobi sits at an elevation of 1,795 meters above sea level, giving it a mild climate despite being near the equator.
The city's name comes from the Maasai phrase 'Enkare Nairobi,' which means 'cool water.'

clues: This island city is known for its white buildings with blue domes.
It was formed by one of the largest volcanic eruptions in recorded history.
fun_fact: Santorini's beaches have black, red, and white volcanic sand!
Some believe this island may be the inspiration for the lost city of Atlantis.
trivia: The entire island is the rim of a massive underwater volcano caldera.
To protect the whitewashed buildings, homeowners must repaint them every year.

clues: Known as the 'Pink City' due to the color of its historic buildings.
Home to elaborate palaces and an astronomical observatory.
fun_fact: The entire city was painted pink in 1876 to welcome Prince Albert and Queen Victoria!
Jaipur was one of the first planned cities in India, designed according to principles of Vastu Shastra.
trivia: The Hawa Mahal (Palace of Winds) has 953 small windows designed to allow royal ladies to observe street festivals without being seen.
The city forms one point of India's popular Golden Triangle tourist circuit, along with Delhi and Agra.

clues: This city awards a famous peace prize every year.
Surrounded by forests and fjords with ski jumps overlooking the city.
fun_fact: Oslo was originally called Christiania for over 300 years before reverting to its original name in 1925!
The city plants approximately 100,000 new trees every year.
trivia: Oslo has the most electric cars per capita of any city in the world.
The famous Edvard Munch painting 'The Scream' is housed in Oslo's National Gallery.

clues: This coastal capital rarely sees rain despite being perpetually cloudy.
Known for its colonial architecture and world-renowned cuisine.
fun_fact: Lima is the second-largest desert city in the world after Cairo!
The city is home to the oldest continuously operating university in the Americas, founded in 1551.
trivia: Lima's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 1,600 balconied houses.
The city was called 'City of Kings' when it was founded by Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro.

clues: This city is home to what was once the world's tallest building from 2004 to 2010.
Known for its vibrant night markets and street food scene.
fun_fact: Taipei 101 has a massive tuned mass damper sphere visible to visitors that stabilizes the building during earthquakes and typhoons!
The city has a 'cat village' where hundreds of stray cats are cared for by local residents.
trivia: Taipei's MRT metro system is so clean that eating, drinking, and chewing gum are banned on trains.
The city has the world's largest collection of Chinese art and artifacts at the National Palace Museum.

clues: This city is known for deep-dish pizza and its windy reputation.
Home to the first skyscraper and famous for its distinctive skyline.
fun_fact: The city reversed the flow of its river in 1900, an engineering marvel of the time!
Chicago's nickname 'The Windy City' may refer to its boastful politicians rather than the weather.
trivia: Chicago dyes its river green every year for St. Patrick's Day.
The Sears Tower (now Willis Tower) held the title of tallest building in the world for nearly 25 years.

clues: This city features a massive golden pagoda visible from many parts of the city.
Once the capital, it's known for its colonial architecture and lush parks.
fun_fact: The Shwedagon Pagoda is believed to contain relics of four different Buddhas and is over 2,500 years old!
The city was known as Rangoon until 1989 when the country changed its name from Burma to Myanmar.
trivia: Many buildings in Yangon still have original British colonial-era elevators that are manually operated.
The city has more colonial-era buildings than any other Southeast Asian city.

clues: This tiny city-state is known for its casino and annual Formula 1 race.
The second-smallest country in the world, famous for its wealth and harbor.
fun_fact: Monaco is smaller than New York's Central Park but is the most densely populated country in the world!
There are more millionaires per capita in Monaco than anywhere else on Earth.
trivia: Monaco's citizens are actually prohibited from gambling in the famous Monte Carlo Casino.
The country has no income tax, which is one reason why it attracts the wealthy.

clues: This planned capital city was built in just 41 months in the 1950s.
From above, the city's layout resembles an airplane or bird.
fun_fact: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site, one of the few modern cities with this designation!
When viewed from above, the main city area forms the shape of an airplane or bow and arrow.
trivia: Brasília was constructed to move Brazil's capital inland from the coastal Rio de Janeiro.
Architect Oscar Niemeyer designed most of the city's distinctive modernist buildings.

clues: This city is known as the 'Jerusalem of Europe' for its religious diversity.
A famous assassination here triggered the start of World War I.
fun_fact: In Sarajevo, you can stand in one spot and see a mosque, Catholic church, Orthodox church, and synagogue!
There's a spot marked in the city where Archduke Franz Ferdinand was assassinated in 1914.
trivia: Sarajevo hosted the 1984 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Games held in a Communist country.
The city is surrounded by the Dinaric Alps and built along the Miljacka River.

clues: This rapidly growing city hosted a major sporting event in 2022.
Known for its futuristic skyline and traditional souq marketplace.
fun_fact: Almost the entire city has been built in the last 40 years, transforming from a small fishing village!
The Museum of Islamic Art in Doha sits on its own artificial island.
trivia: Doha's artificial island called The Pearl covers nearly four million square meters and adds 40km of new coastline.
The city's name means 'big tree' in Arabic, referring to a large tree that once stood at the site.

clues: This high-altitude capital city sits over 2,600 meters above sea level.
Known for its gold museum and vibrant street art scene.
fun_fact: On Sundays, the city closes over 120 kilometers of roads to cars for 'Ciclovía,' allowing citizens to bike, skate, and walk freely!
Bogotá has the largest network of bicycle routes in Latin America, called 'ciclorutas.'
trivia: The city was originally called 'Bacatá' by the indigenous Muisca people before Spanish colonization.
Bogotá's Gold Museum houses over 55,000 pieces, making it one of the most important gold collections in the world.

clues: This green capital is known for its dragon bridges and castle on a hill.
The city has banned cars from its center, making it extremely pedestrian-friendly.
fun_fact: The name is so difficult to pronounce that even locals joke about it - it's pronounced 'Lyoob-lyana'!
Ljubljana Castle was built in the 11th century and offers panoramic views of the entire city.
trivia: The city sits on a natural crossroads of European trade routes, between the Alps and the Adriatic Sea.
Ljubljana's Triple Bridge consists of three separate bridges built side by side, connecting the modern city to the historical town.

clues: Known as the 'Garden City' with a river flowing through its center.
This city rebuilt itself with innovative architecture after a natural disaster.
fun_fact: After the 2011 earthquake, locals built a temporary cathedral out of cardboard tubes that could seat 700 people!
The city has a river called Avon named after the Scottish river, despite having no direct connection to Scotland.
trivia: Christchurch is home to the International Antarctic Centre as it's a gateway city to Antarctica.
The city was named after Christ Church College at Oxford University by English settlers.

clues: This Baltic capital has one of the largest collections of Art Nouveau buildings in the world.
Known for its medieval Old Town and wooden architecture.
fun_fact: The Christmas tree tradition reportedly originated in Riga in 1510, when the first decorated tree was displayed!
Nearly one-third of Latvia's entire population lives in this city.
trivia: Riga's Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 500 buildings in different architectural styles.
The city is home to the world's first publicly available 5G network, launched in 2019.

clues: This city is often called the world's greatest open-air museum.
Built on the site of the ancient Egyptian capital of Thebes.
fun_fact: Luxor Temple is partially buried under the modern city - new discoveries are still being made beneath streets and buildings!
The Valley of the Kings contains over 60 tombs, including that of Tutankhamun.
trivia: Luxor's name comes from the Arabic word for 'palaces' because of the many temples in the area.
The city is divided by the Nile River, with the East Bank focusing on the living and the West Bank dedicated to the dead in ancient times.

clues: This city holds the world record for the highest concentration of white marble buildings.
Known for its elaborate golden statues and fountains.
fun_fact: Ashgabat holds 27 Guinness World Records, including the world's largest indoor Ferris wheel!
The city's name means 'city of love' in Arabic.
trivia: Almost all buildings in central Ashgabat are faced with white marble, using over 4.5 million cubic meters of the material.
The city was completely rebuilt after a devastating earthquake in 1948 that killed nearly two-thirds of the population.

clues: This densely populated capital is home to the oldest Chinatown in the world.
Known for its Spanish colonial architecture and vibrant jeepney transportation.
fun_fact: Manila's Binondo district was established in 1594 as the world's first Chinatown!
The city was completely destroyed during World War II, second only to Warsaw in terms of destruction.
trivia: Manila Bay is famous for having one of the most beautiful sunsets in the world.
The walled city area called Intramuros was the seat of Spanish colonial power for over 300 years.

clues: This hilly capital is known as one of the cleanest cities in Africa.
Plastic bags are banned, and there's a mandatory community cleanup day each month.
fun_fact: Kigali has a monthly mandatory community service day called 'Umuganda' where citizens work together on improvement projects!
The city was barely mentioned in tourist guides before 2000 but is now considered one of Africa's safest capital cities.
trivia: Kigali sits at an elevation of 1,567 meters across four ridges and valleys, giving it the nickname 'Land of a Thousand Hills.'
The city has implemented a complete ban on plastic bags since 2008, one of the first in the world to do so.

clues: This capital city sits at an elevation of 2,850 meters in the Andes.
You can stand with one foot in each hemisphere at a special monument here.
fun_fact: Quito is the closest capital city to the equator and has a monument where you can stand in both hemispheres at once!
The city was the first UNESCO World Heritage site ever declared, along with Krakow, Poland in 1978.
trivia: Due to its high altitude, water boils at about 90°C (194°F) in Quito instead of the usual 100°C (212°F).
The city is surrounded by active volcanoes, including Pichincha which last erupted in 1999.

clues: This port city is known for its white low-rise buildings and mountains meeting the sea.
Home to traditional dhow boats and surrounded by ancient forts.
fun_fact: By law, all buildings in Muscat must be white or off-white and cannot exceed a certain height!
The city's name comes from the Arabic word for 'anchorage' as it has been an important trading port for centuries.
trivia: Muscat has some of the cleanest air of any capital city in the world.
The city's harbor is guarded by two 16th-century Portuguese forts, Al Jalali and Al Mirani.

clues: This is the world's coldest capital city, with temperatures reaching -40°C in winter.
Known for its blend of Soviet architecture, Buddhist temples, and traditional ger districts.
fun_fact: Nearly half of Mongolia's entire population lives in this single city!
Ulaanbaatar has moved location at least 28 times throughout its history before settling in its current location.
trivia: The city was originally a mobile monastery that moved locations every few years before permanently settling.
Ulaanbaatar means 'Red Hero' in Mongolian, named in honor of Mongolia's independence from China.

clues: This city claims the title of 'End of the World' as the southernmost city.
A popular starting point for Antarctic expeditions with colorful buildings against mountain backdrops.
fun_fact: The 'End of the World Train' here is the southernmost functioning railway in the world!
The city has a prison museum that was once an actual prison for Argentina's most dangerous criminals, built in this remote location to prevent escapes.
trivia: Despite being the southernmost city, Ushuaia is not as cold as you might expect due to the moderating effect of the ocean.
The city is surrounded by the Martial Mountains and the Beagle Channel, named after Darwin's ship.
